PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the Patron

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about answering blank spaces. The experience of others or of those who have lived in Western Canada before 1917, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Pioneers: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ). And one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.,
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the Person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about getting all the answers. The only thing we need is your personal experience. We want to hear what you did.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether or not they were born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Past: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Know?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 2, entitled "Pioneer Life: What Would You Like to Know?" will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing and churchwork
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Board
University of Saskatchewan
Saskatoon, Sask., S7N 5E6
1. Your full name: Spencer, P.H.S.

2. Your address: 18448 Hornsby Street, Victoria, B.C.

3. Date: July 19th, 1958

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) St. Bottegall, England

5. What was your father's name and occupation? Dr. Arthur Parrot, M.D.

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) Sep. November, 1912

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. At Picton, Ontario, 1856 in Gordon St., 1871-1872.

I've lived over Edmonton, Alberta, in year 1872, in Alberta.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use it as a small talker.)

I was 22 years old.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

In order to make a living.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)

Through my friends and my own interest in reading.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They were well contented and gave their testimony at the meeting.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)? With a brother.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Steamship, train, and horse stage during the latter part of the journey from Spence Butte, B.C., to Ogden, Idaho.

II. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

We used steamship and horseback for the accommodation. We stopped at the town and temporary hotel at Spokane, Washington, B.C., while the arrangements for the immigrants of our company were made. All passengers of Spencer Butte were situated on C.P.R. some saying they were afraid of the Indians.

14. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

There was no opportunity to do so. By living in Canada he was obliged to dependant on the kindness of cattle and horses.

We used 5 ton oxen and horses for the accommodation. We stopped at the town and two more hotels at Spence Bridge, BC, where we had accommodations for the accommodation. Of course, there were places still further west.

Spence's Bridge is situated on C.P.R., some saying builder silent of Hamilton.
